text:
Hi Guys,

I am having this issue while generating access token using OAuth 2.0. Please help me with this.

Does anyone know if it’s possible to update the property level access to view/edit?
We have a few use cases where we need to regularly update who has access to update a property.
I’d like to automate this — but I can’t seem to find it in the API.

<@U05MSLTLK5F>,

I think you need to make little change in redirect_url
please make change *localhost:5000 --> localhost:5000/oauth-callback* and then try
Does anyone know the timeline for making the invoices API endpoints public by chance?

If I fetch a company with a deactivated owner, it gives me a number for that owner field but if I pull the owners from `/crm/v3/owners` the deactivated owners are not showing up as options – My question is, is there any way to map this deactivated owner id to the name associated with the id?… (the name displays in the crm)
You need to send as url form encoded not raw json as content-type

In your second form example, you’re using checkboxes to determine contact type, but your code snippet is still looking for a `select`-type dropdown element. :sweat_smile:

In general, you’ll have to rework the redirection logic in the second snippet, since the redirection logic assumes that the user can only select one option, but the checkboxes allow them to select many.

Oh my god! I am :woman-facepalming: You know what, this makes complete sense. Because I have always been the one to create forms, and recently, the form I have been trying to make work has checkboxes (_but usually, when I create forms, I use drop downs_) Ahh always the little things. Thank you :pray:

So I assume I would use something like this for checkboxes -

`$form.find('input[type="checkbox"]:checked')`
And then of course all the redirection possibilities due to multiple answers being allowed :woozy_face:

I don’t use JQuery so I can’t say for sure with that snippet — in vanilla JS it would be
`var contactTypes = $form.querySelectorAll('input[type=checkbox]:checked')`, but I’m guessing that `find` does something pretty similar.

And yeah, I don’t envy you having to come up with that redirection logic. Personally, I’d tell my marketers “Nope, they get to pick one, unless you want to build a weighted taxonomy to categorize the different options they can select.”
You're the best, thank you so much!
Of course, good luck!

i’ve created a json piece that maps to inactive users in the past to a catch all user that exists. typically a sales manager or something. then i use a property like “previous user name” and fill that in based upon the mapping. 

so the code looks for inactive users first before looking up to the api. this is my workaround that seems to be okay

Anyone know of a way to track association history between objects? I have a client that is determined that HubSpot or some application is removing associations of their objects… and I don’t know where to begin
i asked in the support ui and it told me <https://share.zight.com/GGudPxYY>
This does not have association history <https://share.zight.com/bLuQYo4Y>
I believe this doesn’t work for custom objects, only default objects

use case: client believes object records are being unassociated by HubSpot, a user, or an integration
because I ask a question and need to immediately figure out how to answer my own question, this is the plan I laid out for this —
I think we could create an audit/crm view process that gives us some more details
Create a workflow that does the following:
• Upon Unit Record creation, delay 1 hour, copy the associated building name to a new property on the Unit - Associated Building Name
• This would store the original association building name on the uni
Then we set up a secondary workflow that would do the following:
• Schedule at 10pm daily (this would allow the api limits to be hit and for this to be complete before morning)
• All units with “Associated Building Name” known
• Check to see if the associated building is still associated. If not, fire an email to both of us (or whomever) with some details on the record. 
This would allow us to find out when these happen and to get them fixed (we could also auto fix them in this workflow based upon the building name and some extra code!)
• This won’t solve HOW this is happening but then we can notice these sooner, review if someone updated that property that day, and say.. well maybe this was a user. If the record wasn’t updated that day -- then we can begin to start questioning HubSpot and send this over to them as a support item with some evidence that it is happening and could be a bug.
Once I see that this is happening I can then debug this a bit more
Have we checked the Audit Logs yet?
